lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: state the distinguishing properties of solids; liquids and gases

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the structures of solids; liquids and gases in terms of particle separation; arrangement and motion

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe changes of state in terms of melting; boiling; evaporating; freezing and condensing

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the effects of temperature and pressure on the volume of a gas

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: explain changes of state in terms of kinetic particle theory; including the interpretation of heating and cooling curves

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: explain; in terms of kinetic particle theory; the effects of temperature and pressure on the volume of a gas

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe and explain diffusion in terms of kinetic particle theory

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe and explain the effect of relative molecular mass on the rate of diffusion of gases

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the differences between elements; compounds and mixtures

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Topic: 2.2 Atomic structure and the Periodic Table
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the structure of the atom as a central nucleus containing neutrons and protons surrounded by electrons in shells

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Topic: 2.2 Atomic structure and the Periodic Table
lessons.Learning Objective: state the relative charges and relative masses of a proton; a neutron and an electron

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Topic: 2.2 Atomic structure and the Periodic Table
lessons.Learning Objective: define proton number / atomic number as the number of protons in the nucleus of an atom

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Topic: 2.2 Atomic structure and the Periodic Table
lessons.Learning Objective: define mass number / nucleon number as the total number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus of an atom

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Topic: 2.2 Atomic structure and the Periodic Table
lessons.Learning Objective: determine the electronic configuration of elements and their ions with proton number 1 to 20; e.g. 2;8;3

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Topic: 2.2 Atomic structure and the Periodic Table
lessons.Learning Objective: state that: (a) Group VIII noble gases have a full outer shell (b) the number of outer shell electrons is equal to the group number in Groups I to VII (c) the number of occupied electron shells is equal to the period number

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: define isotopes as different atoms of the same element that have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: interpret and use symbols for atoms; e.g. 12C; and ions; e.g. 35Cl –

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: state that isotopes of the same element have the same chemical properties because they have the same number of electrons and therefore the same electronic configuration

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: calculate the relative atomic mass of an element from the relative masses and abundances of its isotopes

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the formation of positive ions; known as cations; and negative ions; known as anions

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: state that an ionic bond is a strong electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the formation of ionic bonds between elements from Group I and Group VII; including the use of dot-and-cross diagrams

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the properties of ionic compounds: (a) high melting points and boiling points (b) good electrical conductivity when aqueous or molten and poor when solid

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the giant lattice structure of ionic compounds as a regular arrangement of alternating positive and negative ions

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the formation of ionic bonds between ions of metallic and non-metallic elements; including the use of dot-and-cross diagrams

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: explain in terms of structure and bonding the properties of ionic compounds: (a) high melting points and boiling points (b) good electrical conductivity when aqueous or molten and poor when solid

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: state that a covalent bond is formed when a pair of electrons is shared between two atoms leading to noble gas electronic configurations

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the formation of covalent bonds in simple molecules; including H ; Cl ; H O; CH ; NH and HCl. Use dot-and-cross diagrams to show the electronic configurations in these and similar molecules

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe in terms of structure and bonding the properties of simple molecular compounds: (a) low melting points and boiling points (b) poor electrical conductivity

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the formation of covalent bonds in simple molecules; including CH OH; C H ; O ; CO and N . Use dot-and-cross diagrams to show the electronic configurations in these and similar molecules

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: explain in terms of structure and bonding the properties of simple molecular compounds: (a) low melting points and boiling points in terms of weak intermolecular forces (specific types of intermolecular forces are not required) (b) poor electrical conductivity

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the giant covalent structures of graphite and diamond

lessons.Learning Objective: relate the structures and bonding of graphite and diamond to their uses; limited to: (a) graphite as a lubricant and as an electrode (b) diamond in cutting tools

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the giant covalent structure of silicon(IV) oxide; SiO

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe the similarity in properties between diamond and silicon(IV) oxide; related to their structures

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: describe metallic bonding as the electrostatic attraction between the positive ions in a giant metallic lattice and a ‘sea’ of delocalised electrons

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: explain in terms of structure and bonding the properties of metals: (a) good electrical conductivity (b) malleability and ductility

lessons.Learning Objective: state the formulae of the elements and compounds named in the subject content

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: define the molecular formula of a compound as the number and type of different atoms in one molecule

lessons.Learning Objective: deduce the formula of a simple compound from the relative numbers of atoms present in a model or a diagrammatic representation

lessons.Subject: Chemistry
lessons.Learning Objective: construct word equations and symbol equations to show how reactants form products; including state symbols

lessons.Learning Objective: define the empirical formula of a compound as the simplest whole number ratio of the different atoms or ions in a compound

lessons.Learning Objective: deduce the formula of an ionic compound from the relative numbers of the ions present in a model or a diagrammatic representation or from the charges on the ions
